ygData.subject: Re: ANJI : NEAT implementation (fingerprint implementation issues)
ygData.msgSnippet: Sure, I agree, nodes that allow more than one input source could potentially allow some pretty nifty things to happen.  So by all means we should try different

Sure, I agree, nodes that allow more than one input source could 
potential=
ly allow some pretty nifty things to happen.  So by all 
means we should tr=
y different kinds of nodes that diverge from 
tradition neural networks.  T=
hat's part of why I made the decision to 
call these representations CPPNs =
rather than neural networks.  

In fact, the post to which you just replied=
 described just such an 
activation function, i.e. one that takes two argum=
ents and converts 
their coordinate frame to polar.

ken

--- In neat@yahoo=
groups.com, "afcarl2" <a.carl@...> wrote:
>
> Experiments and open research=
 problems are strongly shaped by the 
> features of the tools employed. The=
 resulting feasibility of a 
useful 
> solution can become nothing more tha=
n a manifestation of the 
> limitations of the tool employed. One-In/One-Ou=
t nodes are too 
> limiting to explore or "experiment" with, to evaluate po=
tential 
> alternative activation functions. It is like trying to paint a 
=
sunset 
> with only black paint on a white canvas. You can identify primary=
 
> features, but it leaves much to be desired.
> 
> Andy Carl
>

> --- =
In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> >
> > Here =
are my thoughts after reading through this very interesting 
> > conversati=
on.
> > 
> > First, I agree rotation is an important issue for HyperNEAT; 
=
> however, 
> > I am confident that is can be dealt with.  It's an interest=
ing 
open 
> > research problem.
> > 
> > In any case, there is an importan=
t aspect of this issue that we 
> > should also be considering.  The proble=
m is not simply to be able 
> to 
> > perform a rotation. As Jason's posts =
imply (and Peter stated), 
> > HyperNEAT and CPPNs should technically alrea=
dy be able to perform 
> > rotations.  And, in fact, they do.  When I play =
with God Mode in 
> > genetic art I often find weights that when adjusted r=
otate a part 
> of 
> > the image.  That is not that unusual (although perh=
aps not as 
usual 
> > as we'd like either).
> > 
> > However, that kind of=
 rotation actually *isn't* the type we 
really 
> > need.  The issue is not=
 that a particular shape should be 
possible 
> to 
> > rotate some arbitra=
ry angle by changing some weights. Recall that 
> > CPPNs work by laying ou=
t coordinate frames within which higher 
> > strucutres are situated.  To c=
reate a symmetric coordinate frame 
> means
> > creating a gradient with *t=
wo* sides, both the opposite of each 
> > other.  That is, symmetry is not =
created by flipping a gradient 
> from 
> > one side to the other, but rath=
er by having both sides at the 
same 
> > time.
> > 
> > Therefore, a rotat=
ional coordinate frame should actually contain 
> > something akin to a sin=
usoidal gradient that spreads around a 
> circle 
> > rather than along a l=
ine. Then, structures situated within its 
> > coordinate frame would repea=
t in a rotated regular pattern, like 
> > petals on a flower (that way you =
get rotatonal invariance).  
> > 
> > Thus what we really want is to be abl=
e to feed in a regular 2D 
> > coordinate frame and output another coordina=
te frame that is a 
sine 
> > wave around a circle in 2D as well.  In other=
 words:
> > 
> > f(x,y)=3Da point in this circular petal-like gradient
> > =

> > Thus we only need to define a function like that and make it an 
> > a=
ctivation function that takes two distinct inputs.
> > 
> > However, the pr=
oblem does remain of where to control the period 
of 
> > repetition around=
 the circle.
> > 
> > Actually, thinking of it now, what we really want is =
NOT what I 
> just 
> > said but rather something a bit different that woul=
d solve the 
> > problem I just posed: What we want is a function f(x,y) th=
at 
> produces 
> > a gradient that starts at 0 on e.g. the x axis and then=
 increases 
> up 
> > to 1 as you rotate around the origin to 360 degrees.
=
> > 
> > That way, you have a true circular/polar coordinate system.  Then =

> you 
> > can simply run its output into a sine wave, and you get the 
> =
> repetition around the circle that I describe above.  Then the 
> > freque=
ncy of repetition is controlled very easily by varying the 
> > weight leav=
ing the polar function and entering the sine wave, 
just 
> > as in any nor=
mal CPPN!
> > 
> > So I guess my conclusion is we just need a function that=
 converts 
> > Cartesian coordinates to a polar angle, and then running its=
 
output 
> > into a periodic activation function will give your nice 
rota=
tional 
> > repetition, which in a neural substrate is rotational invarianc=
e!
> > 
> > Hmm...so I think this explains in part how to deal with the 
is=
sue, 
> > though maybe not 100% (it doesn't explain what it means if the 
>=
 inputs 
> > to such a polar conversion function are not the base-level x a=
nd 
y, 
> > but I think such cases will actually yield nice localized 
> ro=
tational 
> > effects as well).  
> > 
> > Sorry for writing out my thought=
s as they come to me in stream of 
> > consciousness- this is a rare case w=
here I'm thinking of ideas as 
I 
> > write!
> > 
> > ken
